metadata.title: Ionic Conductivity in Ionic Liquid Nano Thin Films

sections.text:
Ionic liquids (ILs) have various interesting properties, suchas low melting points, low vapor pressures, and con-sequently lower volatilities. In addition, ILs are designable uids due to the large selection of cation and anion pairs. The interfacial structures and dynamics of the ILs on solid surfaces1,2 must be understood to engineer IL solid interfacial behaviors especially in the elds of electrochemistry,3 tribology,4 etc.
In general, interfacial liquid molecules have a di erent solvation environment as compared to those in the bulk as they are in contact with either solids or a vacuum. There are two distinct experimental approaches for investigating IL solid interfaces: (1) indirect measurements of the buried interface of a bulk IL and (2) direct investigations of the structure and physical properties of thin lm ILs (TF-ILs) grown on the nanoscale. In the former approach, various sophisticated and sensitive interface analysis techniques, including atomic force microscopy (AFM),5 11 surface force apparatus (SFA),12 18 Xray re ectometry (XRR),8,19,20 neutron re ectometry,21 sumfrequency generation (SFG) spectroscopy,22 28 and surfaceenhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS),29,30 have been employed so far. Most of the results from these techniques indicate pronounced structuring and molecular layering in the
region close to the solid surface within several nanometers. In particular, some SFA studies have revealed that the ILs con ned between two charged solid surfaces with a gap less than 10 nm show a drastic enhancement of their e ective viscosity.15,16 In the latter approach, there have been many attempts to determine the adsorption and the subsequent multilayered structures of IL molecules in the initial deposition of the IL on a solid surface by means of various sensitive surface analysis techniques, such as photoemission spectroscopy (PES),31 38 infrared re ection absorption spectroscopy (IRAS),39 43 time-of- ight secondary ion mass spectrometry (TOF-SIMS),44 46 scanning tunneling microscopy (STM),38,47 49 and AFM.37 However, further deposition of the IL to fabricate its thin lm, owing to the poor wettability of ILs, especially on nonmetallic solid substrates, often results in a nonuniform dispersion of threedimensional (3D) liquid droplets over the substrate. Such a nonuniformity of the IL thin lm hampers the characterization of the IL/substrate interface structures as well as the

macroscopic measurements of their physical properties. If a uniform TF-IL can be prepared with a well-de ned nanoscale thickness, it will be a good model for studying the e ects of the lm thickness and the surface chemical properties of the substrate on the physical properties, such as ionic conductivity, of nanoscale TF-ILs on solid materials.
Computational simulation is a powerful tool for investigating molecular-level phenomena that are often di cult to study only experimentally, though it should use simpli ed models in some cases. Classical molecular dynamics (MD) simulations have been used to study the structures50,51 and dynamics52 54 of ILs at the molecular level. MD simulations have predicted that the di erent lengths of the alkyl chains in the cation a ect the detailed structure of ILs,50,51 which was later con rmed experimentally.55 The capability of MD simulations to estimate the macroscopic physical properties of ILs, such as density, ionic conductivity, viscosity, etc.,53,54 allows for direct comparison with experimental results. Although many MD studies on ILs in the vicinity of solids have focused mainly on the interfacial structure of the ILs near the solids,56 58 information regarding the physical properties of interfacial ILs is still scarce, and the e ects of the liquid thickness on the physical properties are unclear. In addition, to the best of our knowledge, there are no reports of a direct comparison of MD simulations and experimental results in terms of macroscopic physical properties of the nanoscale interfacial ILs.
To obtain basic insight into the ionic conduction behavior of interfacial ILs, we employed a direct approach to investigate the structure and physical properties of a TF-IL, taking advantage of our original nanoscale deposition technique for ILs in a vacuum.59 In this study, we grew uniform IL thin lms of 1- ethyl-3-methylimidazolium bis(tri uoromethylsulfonyl)imide ([emim][TFSA]) with well-de ned thicknesses on the nanoscale on a surface-modi ed, well-wettable sapphire ( - Al2O3(0001)) substrate. From a combined approach of in situ in-plane ionic conductivity measurements of the nanoscale TFIL and MD simulations, the thickness-dependent in-plane ionic conductivity was con rmed. The origin of this behavior is discussed in terms of the liquid structure and the dynamics of the constituent ions.

sections.heading: RESULTS
sections.text:
Improvement of IL Wettability on Sapphire. As already mentioned above, ILs typically form 3D droplets on most solid surfaces( e.g., a single crystal sapphire substrate used in this study). To improve the wettability of the ILs on those substrates, we carried out a wetting layer (WL) treatment60 (Figure 1a): a bulk drop of [emim][TFSA] is evaporated in a tube furnace at 300 °C for 20 min in vacuum. After this treatment, the complete wetting of [emim][TFSA] (the contact angle became <5°) was obtained, and the bare substrate shows a contact angle of 30° (Figure 1b). From the XRR (Supporting Information, Figure S1a), a WL, which has a thickness of a few nanometers and has a density lower than that of the bulk [emim][TFSA], was present on the sapphire surface. From the AFM images (Supporting Information, Figure S1b), the step and terrace structures, which had been clearly seen in the substrate before the treatment, disappeared after the wetting layer formation. From the chemical information from attenuated total re ection Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FT-IR) (Supporting Information, Figure S2a) and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Supporting Information, Figure S2b), the cations might strongly interact (chemisorbed and/or degraded) with and may
be xed on the substrate with the surrounding anions adsorbed in a bulk-like state to neutralize the charges of cations in the WL (Supporting Information, Figure S2c). Unfortunately, the formation process of this WL is not fully understood yet, but the layer is considered to be formed at high temperature during the IL droplet evaporation process because [emim][TFSA] droplet on the substrate without evaporation treatment does not form such a WL with high IL wettability.
Uniform TF-IL Formation on Sapphire. Figure 2 shows a schematic of our vacuum chamber system for IL deposition and
in situ ionic conductivity measurements. We performed the deposition and ac impedance measurements in the same vacuum chamber without breaking the vacuum conditions to minimize the e ects of airborne contamination, such as water and hydrocarbons, on the ionic conductivity (Supporting Information, Figure S3).
We then deposited, for example, 9 nm thick [emim][TFSA] simultaneously on the pristine and 2 nm thick WL-covered sapphire substrates, which were placed next to each other on the sample holder, resulting in completely di erent growth behaviors between the two TF-IL samples. The deposited [emim][TFSA] on the pristine substrate without the WL was a nonuniform dispersion of liquid droplets (Figure 3a), whereas a uniform and smooth thin lm formed on the WL-covered substrate (Figure 3b). In corresponding XRR patterns (Figure 3c), the IL lm sample was at enough to observe thickness
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.8b06386 ACS Nano 2018, 12, 10509 10517 10510
fringes. However, the sample of the droplets showed no fringes. The thickness of the deposited [emim][TFSA] IL layer estimated from the XRR tting (9 nm, Supporting Information, Table S1) is consistent with the e ective thickness estimated from the AFM volume analysis of the droplet sample. In addition, thinner IL samples showed clear XRR fringes and at surfaces (see Supporting Information, Figure S4). For a TF-IL (e.g., the thickness is 6 nm as designed by a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM)) prepared on a WL/sapphire substrate with the comb-shaped electrode pattern, we also con rmed that the thickness was not a ected by the electrodes by directly measuring the thickness of the TF-IL between the electrodes using a synchrotron microbeam XRR (Figure 3d and Supporting Information, Figures S5 and S6). The estimated thickness of the TF-IL between the electrodes by tting was almost identical to that of another TF-IL sample simultaneously deposited on a WL/sapphire substrate without the comb-shaped electrode pattern (Supporting Information, Table S2). In addition, AFM images taken at a position between the electrodes for the same sample also showed that the TF-IL thickness, estimated from the depth of the pinhole defect, was close to the value obtained by
the XRR (Supporting Information, Figure S7). These results suggest that there is no sign of IL migration from the oxide (the WL area) to the metal electrodes on sapphire in our TF-IL samples, di erent from the cases as reported in the literature.61
Thickness Dependence of Ionic Conductivity. Figure 4a,b shows a set of impedance spectra of the droplet and thin lm IL samples with di erent e ective thicknesses measured in the in-plane direction at 298 K. The impedance spectrum of the pristine sapphire substrate without the WL re ects the reaction mainly originating from the geometric capacitance of the combshaped electrode. The spectra did not change signi cantly with an increase in the e ective thickness of the deposited IL (Figure 4a), indicating that the footprints of the droplets are much smaller than the distance between the electrodes (100 m). There is no conduction path between the droplets, meaning that they exhibit insulating-like behavior. In contrast, for the IL thin lms on the WL-covered substrate, the absolute values of the impedance decreased systematically with an increase in the thickness (Figure 4b), con rming that the IL thin lm was continuous enough even on the nanoscale and not composed of IL droplets too small to observe by using AFM. Note that the

impedance spectrum of the wetting-layer-covered substrate is almost identical to that of the pristine substrate, indicating that the WL has negligible conductivity (Figure 4a,b). The ionic conductivity ( ) was calculated from the resistance (R) deduced from the tting of the impedance spectra, using the equation: = L/WtR, where L is the distance between the electrode, W is the length of the electrode, and t is the thickness of the TF-IL. Figure 4c shows the thickness-dependent ionic conductivity for the uniform [emim][TFSA] thin lms. The ionic conductivity value was positively correlated with the thickness when the thickness was less than 10 nm, whereas it was almost constant or showed a slight negative correlation when the thickness was greater than 10 nm. The abrupt decrease in the ionic conductivity value below 10 nm is thought to originate from the structuring and hardening of IL molecules near the solid substrate, as discussed in the next section. However, the ionic conductivity values for the thicker lms ( 5 mS·cm 1) were still lower than the reported bulk value at room temperature ( 9 mS·cm 1 at 298 K).62 This can be attributed to the nonuniformities of the IL lms as discussed later in more detail in the Discussion section.
Structure and Dynamics of TF-IL Investigated by Using MD Simulation. To reveal the structure and dynamics of TF-IL at the molecular level and to assess the e ects of the thickness on the structure and dynamic properties, we performed MD simulations on TF-IL with di erent thicknesses on a hydroxylated sapphire substrate as a model system. Although the e ects of the sapphire substrate on the structure of IL near the solid interface were mentioned in a previous study,56 the e ects of the thickness on the structure and dynamics properties of TF-IL were not revealed. To model TF-ILs with di erent thicknesses, ve TF-ILs consisting of 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 ion pairs were simulated on the same substrate area at 300 K for 10 ns. Figure 5a shows a typical cross-sectional
snapshot of the TF-IL containing 300 ion pairs on the sapphire substrate. The cations and the anions are distributed almost homogeneously. Near the substrate, the ions adsorb on the substrate and are attened. To evaluate the structure near the interface, mass density pro les of TF-ILs with di erent thicknesses were calculated and are shown in Figure 5b. The densities are represented as a function of distance along the outof-plane direction, z-direction, where the interface between the IL and substrate was set as the reference point (z = 0). The mass density arose at about 0.2 nm. There were sharp peaks of 4.0, 2.7, and 1.9 g·cm 3 at 0.3, 0.5, and 0.7 nm from the interface, respectively. The sharp peaks were present in each of the simulated TF-ILs, suggesting the existence of solid-like structuring or a layered structure of IL above the interface
between the IL and the sapphire substrate. From 1.2 nm above the interface, the density was close to the bulk value of 1.50 g· cm 3. Therefore, the layered structure disappears about 1.2 nm from the interface. The density pro les for all TF-ILs within the layered structure region were identical. This shows that the molecular layering structure does not depend on the thin lm thickness. Moreover, we estimated the thicknesses of all TF-ILs: for 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 ion pairs TF-ILs, the thicknesses were approximately 1.93, 3.77, 5.62, 7.45, and 9.30 nm, respectively. For simplicity, hereafter, the 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 ion pairs TF-ILs are referred to by their thicknesses of 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 nm, respectively. The e ects of the IL thickness on the structure of the IL above the substrate have not been reported. Our MD simulations show that the interaction of IL with the sapphire substrate induces a solid-like layered structure of the IL at the IL/sapphire interface and that the layered structure does not depend on the thin lm thickness.
The dynamics of ions in TF-IL is an important aspect to be investigated. It decides the di usion coe cient, ionic conductivity, viscosity, and so on. These properties at the molecular level can be compared with those at the macro level directly. However, the dynamics of the ions in TF-ILs on the sapphire substrate at the molecular level are still unclear, and the e ects of the thickness on the dynamics of the ions have not been reported. Thus, we calculated the mean square displacement (MSD) and estimated the self-di usion coe cient of the TF-IL on the sapphire substrate with di erent thicknesses. To clarify the e ects of the sapphire substrate, we compared the results with and without the substrate. The latter one is referred to as free-standing IL (FS-IL) lm. The simulation snapshot of the FS-IL lm and the mass density pro les of all simulated FS-IL lms are shown in Supporting Information, Figure S8. The selfdi usion coe cient of all cation and anion molecules in all TFILs on the sapphire and FS-IL lms was calculated by using the Einstein relation:

Figure 6a,b shows di usion coe cients of ions for both the TF-IL on the sapphire substrate and FS-IL lm in the in-plane direction, xy-direction (Dxy), and out-of-plane direction, zdirection (Dz), respectively. The values of Dxy and Dz of the bulk state are depicted as horizontal dotted lines. Dxy of TF-IL on the sapphire substrate increased sharply from 2 to 4 nm and then saturated. From 6 to 10 nm, the Dxy values are relatively close to the bulk value but still below it. These behaviors suggest that the substrate suppresses the movement of ions in TF-IL on the sapphire substrate especially in the 2 nm lm and that the e ects of the substrate do not disappear when the thickness is 10 nm. The values of Dz for the FS-IL lms are slightly higher than those for TF-IL on the sapphire substrate with the highest discrepancy for the 2 nm lm. This suggests that the movement of ions in the out-of-plane direction is suppressed by the substrate. In addition, the Dz value of the 10 nm FS-IL lm is still below the bulk value, suggesting that the e ects of the thin lm thickness do not disappear in the 10 nm lm. Overall, the values of Dxy and Dz were the smallest for the 2 nm TF-IL on the sapphire substrate.
To analyze the dynamics of the ions further, we evaluated the MSD in the in-plane direction for three di erent regions: close to the substrate (layered structure region), in the middle of the TF-IL (bulk-like region), and near the vacuum interface (surface region) of the 6 nm TF-IL on the sapphire substrate. The details of the analyses are presented in Supporting Information, Figure S9. We found that the MSD of the ions in the layered structure region was signi cantly lower than that in the other regions. The low MSD in the layered structure region further suggests that the movement of ions is limited by the interaction of the ions with the substrate. Furthermore, it supports the signi cantly low di usion for the 2 nm TF-IL on the sapphire because the 2 nm TF-IL lm on the sapphire substrate has the highest compositional ratio in the layered structure region over its total volume. Moreover, we found that, although the MSD in the surface region was close to that in the bulk-like region, it was slightly higher than that in the bulk-like region. We think that this explains why the Dxy values in the FS-IL lms are slightly higher than that in the bulk because the FS-IL lm has two IL/vacuum interfaces. In fact, Cheung et al. have suggested that the Dxy in a free-standing soap lm63 is faster than that in its bulk state. Thus, it con rms that our MD simulation results are reasonable. It has been suggested that increasing the number of particles in MD simulations provides an increase in the system size, and this eventually leads to a higher value of the self-di usion coe cient due to the hydrodynamics e ects.64 However, the relatively close values of Dxy in the 4 10 nm FS-IL lms as well as in the 6 10 nm TF-IL on the sapphire substrate indicate that the sizedependent e ect is less signi cant compared to the con nement
e ect by the substrate, as shown in the 2 nm TF-IL, in the present case. The limited movement of ions near the substrate in the TF-IL on the sapphire substrate is di cult to study only by experimentation, and therefore, it was investigated by using MD simulations. Here, we evaluated the dynamics of TF-IL on the substrate and revealed the e ects of the thin lm thickness.

sections.heading: DISCUSSION
sections.text:
Uniform nanoscale TF-IL were grown on a modi ed sapphire substrate by using continuous-wave infrared (CW-IR) laser deposition. Moreover, we clari ed the structure and dynamics of TF-IL at the molecular level by using MD simulations. To discuss the e ects of the substrate and thickness on the physical properties of TF-IL on the sapphire substrate further, we directly compared the thickness-dependent ionic conductivity calculated experimentally, shown in Figure 4c, and by using MD simulations. In the experiments, the e ects of the substrate and thickness of the lms are signi cant below 10 nm, and therefore, the conductivities were calculated by using MD simulation only below 10 nm. The ionic conductivity values were calculated by using Nernst Einstein (NE) equation:

Liu et al. have shown that the NE equation can be used to calculate the temperature dependence of ionic conductivity in ILs.53 Although their results slightly underestimate the experimental data, the trends agree well.
Figure 7 shows the thickness-dependent ionic conductivity values obtained experimentally (Figure 4c) and by using MD simulation. To calculate the ionic conductivity values by using MD simulation, we used the in-plane self-di usion coe cient (Dxy). Although there is a discrepancy between the experimental results and MD simulations, the values are on the same order of

It should be pointed out that we could essentially reproduce such thicknessdependent ionic conductivity, though the IL/solid interface structures were slightly di erent between the experiments and MD simulations. In the experiments, the sapphire substrate was covered with a WL. Although some insights into chemical states and molecular structures of the WL are obtained from FT-IR and XPS (Supporting Information, Figure S2), the adsorption structure is still unclear and not enough in detail to model the interface structure for simulation. Therefore, we used a hydroxylated sapphire substrate in the MD simulations as a model of the sapphire substrate.56,65,66
To further compare the results of experiments and MD simulations, we analyzed the thickness-dependent ionic conductivity of the TF-IL by using a multilayer model. Recently, according to Geng et al., the multilayer model has been found to be useful for describing the thickness-dependent properties of polymer lms, such as glass transition temperature, viscosity, and di usivity,67,68 in which the polymer lm is divided into several layers, with each layer having a di erent degree of mobility.68 As mentioned in the previous section (see also Supporting Information, Figure S9), the in-plane MSD of ions in the region near the IL/substrate interface (layered structure region) is signi cantly lower than that in the region in the middle of the TF-IL (bulk-like region) and the region near the IL/ vacuum interface (surface region). Although the surface region exhibited a MSD slightly higher than that of the bulk-like region, the di erence in the MSDs in both regions was very small. Therefore, a two-layer model (inset Figure 7) involving an interfacial layer above the substrate with a low mobility of ions and a bulk-like layer with a mobility close to the bulk state is su cient for the present case. The interfacial layer has a thickness of di and a conductivity of i. The bulk-like layer has a thickness of d di and a conductivity of b, where d represents the total thickness of the TF-IL. Values of b for the experiments and MD simulations were xed at 9.0 mS·cm 1 (the experimental value of the bulk state from the literature62) and 7.2 mS·cm 1 (the bulk value obtained by MD simulation), respectively. On the other hand, the di, i, and values were varied to produce the best tting. Both experimental and simulation data were tted by using eq 3, as shown by the solid line in Figure 7. For the experimental data, the best tting parameters of di, i, and are 2.7 nm, 2.9 mS·cm 1, and 0.56, respectively. We propose that the physical interpretation of the prefactor is related to the nonuniformity of the TF-IL, such as dewetting actually seen in the experiment. There are two types of dewetting: (1) microscopic defects in the IL lm with a scale typically below 1 m in diameter, which might be caused by the microscopic defects/nonuniformity of the wetting layer, and (2) a smaller wetting region (droplet formation) especially found at the outer region of the IL lm, which occurs via the dewetting of an IL drop during the wetting layer treatment (see details in Supporting Information, Figure S10). Because the origin of these dewettings is basically the nonuniformity of the wetting layer, the prefactor would take a speci c value depending on the samples and should be constant throughout one sample
during the repeated cycles of IL deposition and ionic conductivity measurement to obtain a series of thicknessdependent conductivity data from the one sample. Therefore, the observed thickness-dependent behavior of the conductivity originates rather from the intrinsic thickness-dependent structure. In fact, the prefactor varies slightly sample by sample because the nonuniformity of the wetting layer is di erent between the samples, but the two-layer model can be adopted to well-reproduce the thickness-dependent conductivity for all of the samples (see Supporting Information, Figure S11).
For the MD simulation data, di, i, and were 1.6 nm, 3.0 mS· cm 1, and 1.0, respectively. Since for the MD simulations is equal to 1.0, the tting parameters can be directly compared with the actual data. The value of di for the MD simulations is relatively close to the thickness of the layered structure region ( 1.2 nm), mentioned previously. In addition, the value of i for MD simulations is close to the conductivity in the 2 nm TF-IL ( 3.97 mS·cm 1). Thus, those results validate the two-layer model approach for modeling the thickness dependent ionic conductivity of TF-ILs on the sapphire substrate. The value of di for the experiment is 2.7 nm, higher than that for the MD simulations. The value of di in the experiment is somewhat close to the thickness of the solvation layer structure (2.8 nm) of [emim][TFSA] on Au(111) determined by using AFM force pro les.6 It is probably because the IL/sapphire interface structures are di erent between the experiments and MD simulations as mentioned above, giving di erent interfacial interactions. Nevertheless, the applicability of the two-layer model to describe the thickness dependence of ionic conductivity in both experiments and MD simulations suggests that the essential behavior of ionic conductivity of the solid-like IL near the solid is not so di erent for di erent interactions at IL/solid interfaces.

sections.heading: CONCLUSION
sections.text: In summary, the thin lm approach in this study utilizing our precision preparation of uniform TF-IL samples with wellde ned lm thicknesses on the nanoscale together with in situ ionic conductivity measurements and MD simulations is a powerful method for understanding the dynamics and underlying physics of nanoscale interfacial ILs in the vicinity of solids. The mechanisms show how the wetting layer works for improving the wettability of IL, and the molecular level insights on the interfacial structure between IL and the wetting layer will be further investigated in our future work. The present results showed that the ionic conductivity of the TF-IL decreased with a decrease in the thin lm thickness, and that the empirical twolayer model could be used to t both experimental and simulation data well. The basis for the applicability of the twolayer model lies in the solid-like structuring of IL near the solid substrate as is revealed in the MD simulations. Our experimental study in conjunction with MD simulations is therefore important, providing the insight into the properties of nanoscale ILs, which are di erent from the bulk. The present results will be also bene cial for further studying or designing other nanoscale ILs near solid systems.

sections.heading: METHODS
sections.text:
Deposition of IL. The [emim][TFSA] (IL) was deposited by using a CW-IR laser deposition technique59 in a high-vacuum chamber with a base pressure of 10 7 Torr. A pulse-modulated CW-IR laser (808 nm, 250 W·cm 2, 20 ms pulse, 4 Hz) was irradiated onto the IL target with
DOI: 10.1021/acsnano.8b06386 ACS Nano 2018, 12, 10509 10517 10514
powder Si contained together, which helps to absorb the laser. The deposition amount was carefully monitored by using a QCM.
In Situ Impedance Measurement. An Au ( 100 nm)/Ni Cr ( 30 nm) comb-shaped electrode (electrode distance = 100 m, comb width = 100 m, comb length = 5000 m; the number of combs on one side = 22) was deposited prior to the IL deposition by using thermal evaporation with a metal mask. In situ impedance measurements were performed just after the IL deposition without breaking the vacuum conditions in a frequency range of 100 kHz to 0.01 Hz. Ionic conductivity was estimated from the tting of impedance spectra using an equivalent circuit shown in Supporting Information, Figure S12.
Ex SituCharacterizations. AFM images were measured by SPA400 (Seiko Instruments Inc.) with a tapping mode using soft cantilevers (SI-DF3, Hitachi High-Tech Science Corporation, typical spring constant of 1.6 N/m, a tip radius of 10 nm). Laboratory XRR was measured with a D8 Discover (Bruker Corporation). Synchrotron microbeam XRR was conducted at SPring-8 on the Beamline BL46XU with an X-ray energy of 12.39 keV ( = 1 Å) using a point detector (see Supporting Information, Figure S5). ATR-FT-IR spectra were measured by MIRacle10 (Shimazu Corporation). X-ray photoemission spectroscopy was performed by AXIS-ULTRA (Shimadzu Corporation) with monochromatic Al K radiation (1486.7 eV) operating at 300 W.
MD Simulation. The [emim][TFSA] (IL) molecules and the fully hydroxylated sapphire substrate were represented by using a unitedatom (UA) model54 and all-atomic model using ClayFF force eld,69 respectively. The UA model for the IL and the atomic representation of the sapphire substrate are shown in Supporting Information, Figure S13. The UA model and ClayFF force eld consist of bonded and nonbonded terms. The bonded term in the UA model is represented by bonding, bending, and dihedral potentials, whereas the bonded term in the ClayFF force eld consists of bonding and bending potentials. The nonbonded interactions in the UA model, ClayFF force eld, and between them are represented by Lennard-Jones (LJ, 6 12 form) and Coulomb potentials to describe the van der Waals and electrostatic interactions, respectively. In the UA model, the total charges of the cation and anion are rescaled to ±0.8e to account for the polarization e ects.54 The detailed formulations of the force eld are given in Supporting Information, Note 1. Lorentz Berthelot mixing rules were used for combining all of the LJ interaction parameters. A cuto distance of 12 Å was used to evaluate the LJ and short-range Coulomb interaction.
For atoms present within the same molecule in the IL, the nonbonded interactions were not counted if two atoms were separated by less than three consecutive bonds, and a scaling coe cient of 0.5 was applied if two atoms were separated by three consecutive bonds. All parameters for simulating IL and the sapphire substrate are given in Supporting Information, Note 2. The IL and the sapphire substrate were put inside a simulation box. The length of the sapphire substrate along the x- and y-directions, which were set as the length of the simulation box along the x- and y-directions, was 47.59 and 49.46 Å, respectively. The substrate had a thickness of 12.52 Å along the zdirection. The length of the simulation box along the z-direction (Lz) for the 100, 200, 300, 400, and 500 ion pairs were 70, 90, 110, 130, and 150 Å, respectively.
In our MD simulations, the equation of motion was integrated by using a velocity Verlet algorithm70 with time step of 2 fs. All production runs were conducted in the NVT ensemble for 10 ns, in which the temperature was kept constant by using a Nose Hoover thermostat71 with a relaxation time of 0.2 ps. Before the production run, equilibration procedures were done by using a heating process at 600 K for 4 ns, cooling to 300 K for 2 ns, and relaxing at 300 K for 4 ns. In some cases, the relaxation was extended for another 4 8 ns to ensure the equilibration. The bulk IL was equilibrated in the NPT ensemble, in which the volume of the bulk cell was calculated for the subsequent production run in the NVT ensemble. The pressure was kept constant at 0 atm to replicate the vacuum condition by using a Nose Hoover barostat72 with a relaxation time of 2 ps. Periodic boundary conditions were applied in three dimensions. The simulations for TF-IL on the sapphire and FS-IL lm were performed in a 2D manner by adding a
vacuum space along the z-direction. The length of the vacuum space was 3 times the initial Lz. The long-range electrostatic interactions were calculated by using Ewald summation.73 The slab model74 was used to calculate the long-range electrostatic interactions in TF-IL on the sapphire and FS-IL lm, which is related to the addition of the vacuum space mentioned previously. The self-di usion coe cient and ionic conductivity data calculated from our MD simulations were the average values obtained from three di erent trajectories with di erent initial con gurations of IL.

metadata.abstractText: Thin lm approaches are powerful methods for gaining a nanoscale understanding of interfacial ionic liquids (ILs) in the vicinity of solids. These approaches are used to directly elucidate the interfacial contributions to the physical properties of ILs as nanoscale thin lms have signi cant proportions of the surface or interface region with respect to their total volume. Here, we report the growth of a uniform [emim][TFSA] thin lm ionic liquid on a chemically modi ed, well-wettable sapphire, thereby allowing the in situ measurement of its ionic conductivity on the nanoscale. We observed the thickness-dependent behavior of the ionic conductivity, which gradually decreased especially when the thickness was less than 10 nm, and found it to be quantitatively analyzed well by using an empirical two-layer model. The molecular dynamics (MD) simulations show that the thicknessdependent ionic conductivity originates from the solid-like structuring of the IL near the substrate, reproducing a thickness-dependent ionic conductivity. The MD simulation results suggest that the thickness of the low conductivity region determined in the two-layer model should roughly correspond to the thickness of the solid-like structuring of the IL near the substrate.
